CatDescriptText: Cutline of image published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, June 18, 1949, p. 4, reads: "Accused Policemen Cleared by Trial Board - Waiting to Testify...Pictured above are some of the many people who packed the hearing rooms at the trial of officers Karl C. [O.] Jackson and John Hicks on Wednesday. Left to right, are: Mrs. Lula Hatcher, Fifth Ward committeewoman; The Rev. Charles Foggie, Bishop McLloyd, James Brown, Fifth Ward politician; Ely Randolph, William Davis and Arizona Nicholson.  The Rev. Mr. Foggie is pastor of Wesley Center Church which is the church home of both defendants.  Mr. Nicholson is superintendent of the Sunday school at the same church.  Both Mr. Davis and Mr. Randolph are businessmen in Herron Avenue District. - Harris Photo."  Portion of accompanying article reads: "Clark Watts Denies Politics Influenced Filing of Charges - Witnesses of All Races Crowd Trial Room; Wait Throughout Five-Hour Session to Defend Character of Officers Jackson and Hicks - 'Big Brass' of the city's police department, headed by Col. George E. A. Fairley, director of public safety, heard a public airing. Wednesday, of charges that two Hill District police officers were 'aiding and abetting hoodlumism' against a legitimate businessman whom they had allegedly tried to force into the rackets.  The hearing, attended my more than fifty Herron Avenue district businessmen and citizens brought together for the first time Officers Karl C. [O.] Jackson and John Hicks, and their accuser, Clark Watts.  Mrs. Watts is the owner of the Watts' Brothers Cleaner Shop, 2931 Wylie Avenue, an establishment he claimed was coveted by the officers who wished to use it for illegal and illicit purposes..."
TitMainTitle: Group portrait of Lula Hatcher, Rev. Charles Foggie, Bishop McLloyd, James Brown, Ely Randolph, William Davis, and Arizona Nicholson, posed outside of hearing room
